17.q: What promise did God make concerning Ishmael?

17.a: On that same day, Abraham circumcised all the males of his household.
17.q: After God left Abraham, what did Abraham do on that same day?

17.a: Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
17.q: How old was Ishmael when he was circumcised?

18.a: Abraham saw three men standing across from him.
18.q: As Abraham was sitting at his tent door, what did he see when he looked up?

18.a: Abraham offered the men some water to wash, and some food.
18.q: What did Abraham offer the men?

18.a: The one visitor said that when he returned, Sarah would have a son.
18.q: What prediction did the one visitor give concerning Sarah?
Where was Sarah when the visitor gave his prediction?

18.a: Sarah laughed to herself when she heard the visitor's prediction.
18.q: How did Sarah respond to the visitor's prediction?

18.a: Yahweh asked why Sarah laughed, and said "Is anything too hard for Yahweh"?
18.q: What did Yahweh, the visitor, say about Sarah's response?

18.a: The men left Abraham's home and went toward Sodom.
18.q: When the men left Abraham's home, toward where did they go?

18.a: Yahweh said, "Shall I hide from Abraham what I am about to do"?
18.q: What question did Yahweh ask as they walked?

18.a: Yahweh said that Abraham must instruct his children and his household to do righteousness and justice.
18.q: What did Yahweh say Abraham must do so that Yahweh might fulfill the promises given to Abraham?

18.a: The men were going toward Sodom because the cries against Sodom and Gomorrah were great, and they wanted to see if the cities were as wicked as the outcry suggested.
18.q: Why were the men going toward Sodom?

18.a: Abraham asked, "Will you sweep away the righteous with the wicked"?
18.q: As Abraham stood with Yahweh, what question did he ask Yahweh?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were fifty righteous within the city?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were forty-five righteous within the city?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were forty righteous within the city?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were thirty righteous within the city?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were twenty righteous within the city?

18.a: Yahweh said he would spare the whole place for their sake.
18.q: What did Yahweh say he would do if there were ten righteous within the city?

19.a: Lot offered that they stay at his home for the night, and then leave in the morning.
19.q: When Lot saw the two angels coming into Sodom, what did he offer them?

19.a: The angels said that they would spend the night in the town square.
19.q: What was the angels' response to Lot?

19.a: Finally, the angels went with Lot to his home for the night.
19.q: At Lot's urging, where did the angels finally decide to spend the night?

19.a: The men wanted Lot to bring out the two men visiting him, so they could sleep with them.
19.q: What did the men of the city who surrounded Lot's house want Lot to do?

19.a: Lot offered the men of the city his two daughters instead of the two visitors.
19.q: What did Lot offer the men of the city instead?

19.a: The men told Lot to stand back and almost broke down the door.
19.q: How did the men respond to Lot's offer?

19.a: The angels pulled Lot back into the house and struck the men outside with blindness.
19.q: What did the angels then do?

19.a: The angels said they had been sent to destroy the city.
19.q: What did the angels say they had been sent to do by Yahweh?

19.a: Lot's sons-in-law thought Lot was joking.
19.q: How did Lot's sons-in-law respond when Lot told them to hurry and leave Sodom because it was about to be destroyed?

19.a: The angels told Lot to take his wife and daughters and get out of the city.
19.q: When morning dawned, what did the angels tell Lot to do?

19.a: The angels set them outside the city because Yahweh was merciful to them.
19.q: Why, despite Lot's lingering, did the angels bring Lot and his family by their hands out of the city?

19.a: The angels told Lot and his family to flee for their lives and to not look back.
19.q: What instructions did the angels give Lot when they were outside the city?

19.a: Lot and his family were allowed to flee to a small city called Zoar.
19.q: Where did the angel allow Lot and his family to flee?

19.a: Yahweh rained down sulfur and fire from the sky on Sodom and Gomorrah.
19.q: What did Yahweh do when Lot reached Zoar?

19.a: Lot's wife looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
19.q: What did Lot's wife do and what happened to her?

19.a: Abraham saw smoke rising from the land like the smoke of a furnace.
19.q: What did Abraham see early in the morning as he looked down at all the land of the plain?

19.a: Lot then moved to the mountains because he was afraid to live in Zoar.
19.q: To where did Lot then move and why?

19.a: Lot's daughters planned to make their father drunk, then lie with him so that they could have children.
19.q: What plan did Lot's daughters make involving their father?

19.a: The Moabite and Ammonite people groups came from the daughters of Lot.
19.q: Which two people groups came from the daughters of Lot?

20.a: Abraham said that Sarah was his sister.
20.q: What did Abraham say about Sarah while he was living at Gerar?

20.a: God came to Abimelech in a dream and told him that he was a dead man because he had taken a man's wife.
20.q: What did God say to Abimelech after he took Sarah?

20.a: Abimelech said to God that Abraham had told him Sarah was his sister, and Sarah had told him Abraham was his brother.
20.q: What did Abimelech say to God he had been told by Abraham and Sarah?

20.a: God told Abimelech to return Sarah to Abraham; otherwise, he and all his people would die.
20.q: What did God tell Abimelech to do, and what did God say would happen if he did not do it?

20.a: Abimelech's men were very afraid when they heard what God had told him.
20.q: How did Abimelech's men respond when they heard what God had told Abimelech?

20.a: Abraham said that he was afraid Abimelech would kill him because of Sarah.
20.q: Why did Abraham say he had told Abimelech that Sarah was his sister?

20.a: Sarah was the daughter of Abraham's father, but not of his mother.
20.q: In what way was Sarah actually Abraham's sister?

20.a: Abimelech gave Abraham sheep and oxen, male and female slaves.
20.q: What animals and people did Abimelech give Abraham?

20.a: Abimelech told Sarah he had given a thousand pieces of silver to her brother to cover any offense against Sarah in the eyes of all that were with Sarah, and before everyone.
20.q: What reason did Abimelech give Sarah as to why he gave her brother a thousand pieces of silver?

20.a: God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female slaves so they were able to have children.
20.q: What happened when Abraham prayed to God for Abimelech and his people?

21.a: Yahweh visited Sarah and she bore a son to Abraham at the promised time.
21.q: What did Yahweh do for Sarah?

21.a: When Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him.
21.q: When Isaac was eight days old, what did Abraham do?

21.a: Sarah said that God had made her laugh.
21.q: What did Sarah say God had made her do?

21.a: Sarah saw the son of Hagar mocking.
21.q: On the day Isaac was weaned, what did Sarah see?

21.a: Sarah told Abraham to drive out Hagar and her son, because Hagar's son would not be heir with Isaac.
21.q: What did Sarah tell Abraham to do with Hagar and her son, and why?

21.a: Abraham was grieved by Sarah's demand.
21.q: What was Abraham's reaction to Sarah's demand?

21.a: God told Abraham to listen to Sarah.
21.q: What did God tell Abraham to do?

21.a: Hagar and her son went into the wilderness.
21.q: Where did Hagar and her son go after Abraham sent them out?

21.a: God said he would make the son of Hagar into a great nation.
21.q: What did God tell Hagar he would do for her son?

21.a: God opened Hagar's eyes and she saw a well of water.
21.q: How did Hagar and her son survive?

21.a: Hagar's son became and archer and his mother got a wife for him from Egypt.
21.q: What happened to Hagar's son as he grew up?

21.a: Abimelech wanted Abraham to swear that he would not deal falsely with Abimelech, or with his children, or with his descendants. Abimelech asked Abraham to show to him the same covenant faithfulness that Abimelech had shown to Abraham.
21.q: What did Abimelech want Abraham to swear to do for him?

21.a: Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech's servants had seized from him.
21.q: What did Abraham complain about to Abimelech?

21.a: Abraham sent seven female lambs to Abimelech as a witness that he had dug the disputed well.
21.q: Why did Abraham send seven female lambs to Abimelech?

21.a: Abimelech returned into the land of the Philistines.
21.q: Into what land did Abimelech return?

21.a: Abraham worshiped Yahweh, the eternal God.
21.q: What did Abraham do at the tamarisk tree in Beer-sheba?

21.a: Abraham lived in the land of the Philistines for many days.
21.q: Where did Abraham live for many days?

22.a: God told Abraham to go the land of Moriah and offer Isaac as a burnt offering.
22.q: What test did God give Abraham?

22.a: Abraham rose early in the morning and set out on his journey to the place God had told him about.
22.q: How did Abraham respond to God's command?

22.a: Abraham told his two young men that he and Isaac were going to worship and then would return.
22.q: What did Abraham tell his two young men that he and Isaac were going to do?

22.a: Isaac asked Abraham, "Where is the lamb for the burnt offering"?
22.q: What question did Isaac ask Abraham as they were walking together?

22.a: Abraham said that God would himself provide the lamb for the burnt offering.
22.q: How did Abraham answer Isaac's question?

22.a: Abraham prepared Isaac as the burnt offering by binding him and laying him on the altar.
22.q: When they reached the place, what did Abraham prepare as the burnt offering and how did he do it?

22.a: The angel of Yahweh told Abraham to not harm Isaac.
22.q: When Abraham took the knife in his hand, what did the angel of Yahweh tell Abraham?

22.a: The angel said that he now knew that Abraham feared God.
22.q: What did the angel say he now knew about Abraham?

22.a: There was a ram caught in the bushes behind Abraham, which Abraham used as the burnt offering.
22.q: How did God then provide the burnt offering for Abraham?

22.a: Abraham called the place, "Yahweh will provide".
22.q: What did Abraham call the place of the burnt offering?

22.a: The angel of Yahweh said he would bless Abraham because Abraham had not withheld his only son.
22.q: What reason did the angel of Yahweh give for blessing Abraham?

22.a: Through Abraham's offspring all the nations of the earth were to be blessed, because Abraham had obeyed the angel of Yahweh's voice.
22.q: Through who and why were all nations of the earth to be blessed?

23.a: When Sarah died, Abraham first mourned for her and wept for her.
23.q: What did Abraham first do when Sarah died?

23.a: Abraham asked for a property to use as a burying-place.
23.q: What request did Abraham make to the sons of Heth?

23.a: The sons of Heth offered the choicest of their tombs to Abraham.
23.q: How did the sons of Heth respond to Abraham's request?

23.a: Ephron offered to give Abraham the cave and the field next to it.
23.q: When Abraham asked for Ephron the Hittite's cave as a tomb, how did Ephron respond?

23.a: Abraham offered to pay for the field and the cave.
23.q: How did Abraham respond to Ephron's offer?

23.a: Ephron asked for four hundred shekels of silver for the field and the cave.
23.q: How did Ephron respond to Abraham's offer?

23.a: Abraham paid four hundred shekels of silver to Ephron for the piece of land.
23.q: How did the conversation between Abraham and Ephron end?

23.a: The field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were in the field and all around its border were included in Abraham's purchase of the field of Ephron.
23.q: What was included in the purchase of the field of Ephron which was in Machpelah?

23.a: Abraham then buried Sarah in the cave.
23.q: What did Abraham then do with the cave?

24.a: Abraham made his oldest servant swear that he would get a wife for Isaac from Abraham's relatives.
24.q: What did Abraham make his oldest servant swear to do?

24.a: Abraham insisted that the servant not take Isaac back to the land from which Abraham came.
24.q: What did Abraham insist that the servant not do with Isaac?

24.a: The servant asked that the woman whom he asked to lower her pitcher to get a drink would do so and offer to water his camels also.
24.q: What did Abraham's servant ask God to do in order to show him which woman God had chosen for Isaac?

24.a: Rebekah was the granddaughter of Nahor, Abraham's brother.
24.q: What relation was Rebekah to Abraham?

24.a: Rebekah gave the servant a drink.
24.q: What did Rebekah do when Abraham's servant asked for a drink of water?

24.a: After Rebekah finished giving the servant a drink she said, "I will draw water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking."
24.q: What did Rebekah say after she had finished giving the servant a drink?

24.a: The servant worshipped Yahweh and blessed him.
24.q: What did the servant do when he heard that Rebekah was related to Abraham and that he could spend the night with her family?

24.a: Laban was Rebekah's brother.
24.q: Who was Rebekah's brother?

24.a: Laban invited Abraham's servant to stay at his house.
24.q: What did Laban do when he met Abraham's servant?

24.a: Abraham's servant insisted on saying why he had come before he ate.
24.q: What did Abraham's servant insist on doing before he ate?

24.a: Abraham had said that Yahweh would send his angel with the servant to prosper his way.
24.q: How had Abraham said that Yahweh would prosper the servant's way?

24.a: Abraham's servant had given Rebekah a gold ring for her nose and bracelets for her arms.
24.q: What had the servant given Rebekah when he heard she was related to Abraham?

24.a: Laban and Bethuel answered that the servant should take Rebekah and go, so that Rebekah could be the wife of Abraham's son.
24.q: How did Laban and Bethuel answer Abraham's servant when he asked them what they wanted to do regarding Rebekah?

24.a: The servant bowed down to Yahweh and gave gifts to Rebekah and to her brother and mother.
24.q: What did Abraham's servant do when he heard the answer from Laban and Bethuel?

24.a: When they arose the next morning, they wanted Abraham's servant to stay with them for at least ten more days.
24.q: When they arose the next morning, what did Rebekah's brother and mother want the servant to do?

24.a: Rebekah said that she wanted to go with the servant.
24.q: When Abraham's servant said that he wanted to go immediately, what did Rebekah say that she wanted to do?

24.a: Rebekah's family blessed her that she might be the mother of thousands and ten thousands, and that her descendants might possess the gate of those who hate them.
24.q: What blessing did Rebekah's family give her as she left with Abraham's servant?

24.a: Isaac was out in the field meditating.
24.q: What was Isaac doing when Rebekah arrived at his home?

24.a: When she saw Isaac, Rebekah jumped down from the camel and covered herself with her veil.
24.q: What did Rebekah do when she saw Isaac?

24.a: Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah's tent and took Rebekah as his wife.
24.q: What did Isaac do after Abraham's servant recounted all the things that he had done?

25.a: Abraham took another wife named Keturah.
25.q: What did Abraham do after his wife Sarah died?

25.a: Abraham gave gifts to the sons of his concubines, and gave all that he owned to Isaac.
25.q: How did Abraham distribute his wealth?

25.a: Abraham lived one hundred seventy-five years.
25.q: How many years did Abraham live?

25.a: Both Isaac and Ishmael buried Abraham.
The twelve sons of Ishmael lived with each other in hostility.
25.q: How did the twelve sons of Ishmael live with each other?

25.a: Isaac prayed to Yahweh for his wife, and Yahweh answered his prayer, and Rebekah conceived.
25.q: What did Isaac do because Rebekah was childless?

25.a: Yahweh said that there were two nations in her womb, one people stronger than the other, and that the older would serve the younger.
25.q: What did Yahweh say concerning the two children struggling within Rebekah's womb?

25.a: Esau was born first, and he was red all over like a hairy garment.
25.q: Who was born first, and what did he look like?

25.a: Jacob was born second, and he was grasping Esau's heel as he was born.
25.q: Who was born second, and what was he doing as he was born?

25.a: Esau was a skillful hunter and a man of the field.
25.q: What kind of man was Esau?

25.a: Jacob was a quiet man who spent his time in the tents.
25.q: What kind of man was Jacob?

25.a: Isaac loved Esau, and Rebekah loved Jacob.
25.q: Who did Isaac love, and who did Rebekah love?

25.a: Edom was another name for Esau.
25.q: What was another name for Esau?

25.a: Jacob asked for Esau's birthright in return for the red stew.
25.q: For what did Jacob ask in return for the red stew that Esau wanted to eat because he was starving?

25.a: Esau swore an oath and sold his birthright to Jacob.
25.q: What was Esau's response to Jacob's offer?

25.a: Esau was despising his birthright when he responded to Jacob's offer in this way.
25.q: How was Esau treating his birthright when he responded in this way to Jacob's offer?

26.a: Isaac moved to Gerar because there was a famine in the land.
26.q: Why did Isaac move to the city of Gerar where Abimelech was the king of the Philistines?

26.a: Yahweh had told Isaac not to move to Egypt, and to stay in the land about which he would tell Isaac.
26.q: What had Yahweh told Isaac before Isaac moved to Gerar?

26.a: Yahweh told Isaac that he would fulfill the oath which Yahweh had sworn to Abraham.
26.q: What did Yahweh tell Isaac about the oath Yahweh had sworn to his father Abraham?

26.a: Yahweh said he was going to do this because Abraham had obeyed his voice and kept his instructions, commandments, statutes, and laws.
26.q: Why did Yahweh say he was going to do this?

26.a: Isaac told the men of Gerar that Rebekah was his sister.
26.q: What did Isaac say to the men of Gerar about Rebekah, his wife?

26.a: Because of Isaac's lie, someone could have had sexual relations with Rebekah and brought guilt upon the people.
26.q: According to Abimelech, what could have brought guilt upon the people because of Isaac's lie?

26.a: Abimelech commanded that anyone who touched Rebekah would be put to death.
26.q: What command did Abimelech give regarding Rebekah?

26.a: Abimelech asked Isaac to move away from the Philistines because he said, "...for you are mightier than we."
26.q: What reason did Abimelech give for asking Isaac to move away from the Philistines?

26.a: Isaac had to dig out the wells of water which they had dug in the days of Abraham because the Philistines had stopped them up after Abraham's death.
26.q: Why did Isaac have to dig out the wells of water which they had dug in the days of Abraham?

26.a: Isaac named the well, over which the herdsmen of Gerar did not quarrel with him, Rehoboth.
26.q: What did Isaac name the well over which the herdsmen of Gerar did not quarrel with him?

26.a: Yahweh reaffirmed that he would bless Isaac and multiply his descendants.
26.q: What did Yahweh reaffirm to Isaac when he appeared to Isaac at Beersheba?

26.a: Abimelech wanted to make a covenant that neither side would harm the other, because he saw that Yahweh was with Isaac.
26.q: What covenant did Abimelech want to make with Isaac, and why?

26.a: Isaac made a feast, and they swore an oath with each other.
26.q: How did Isaac respond to Abimelech's request for a covenant between them?

26.a: The two wives of Esau were from the Hittites.
26.q: From what people group were the two wives of Esau?

26.a: Esau's wives brought sorrow to Isaac and Rebekah.
26.q: How was the relationship between Esau's wives and Isaac and Rebekah?

27.a: As Isaac grew old, he was no longer able to see.
27.q: As Isaac grew old, what was he no longer able to do?

27.a: Isaac asked Esau to go hunt and make the sort of food that he loved, so that he could eat it and bless Esau.
27.q: What did Isaac ask Esau to do, and why?

27.a: Rebekah told Jacob to go get two goats and she would make the food that Isaac loved, so that Jacob could take it to Isaac and receive the blessing.
27.q: What was Rebekah's plan for providing the food for Isaac, and why?

27.a: Jacob was concerned that Esau was a hairy man and he was a smooth man, and that Isaac would touch him and find out that Jacob was a deceiver and curse him.
27.q: About what was Jacob concerned in bringing the food to Isaac?

27.a: Rebekah put Esau's clothes on Jacob and put goatskins upon his hands and neck.
27.q: How did Rebekah solve the problem of Esau being a hairy man, and Jacob a smooth man?

27.a: Jacob said that Yahweh, Isaac's God, had brought the game to him.
27.q: When Isaac asked, how did Jacob say he had found the game so quickly?

27.a: Isaac touched Jacob on the hands and felt the hairy goatskins.
27.q: Because he was not sure, how did Isaac try to determine who was giving him the food?
What did Jacob say when Isaac asked, "Are you really my son Esau"?

27.a: When Jacob came near Isaac to kiss him, Isaac smelled Esau's clothes.
27.q: What finally convinced Isaac that the person bringing the food was Esau?

27.a: Isaac said nations would bow down to Jacob and that Jacob's mother's sons would bow down to him.
27.q: Who did Isaac say would bow down to Jacob?

27.a: Esau came in from hunting, prepared the food, and brought it to Isaac.
27.q: What did Esau do soon after Jacob left Isaac's tent?

27.a: Isaac said that Jacob had deceitfully taken away Esau's blessing.
27.q: What did Isaac say when Esau asked for Isaac's blessing?

27.a: Esau said that Jacob had cheated him from his birthright and from his blessing.
27.q: In what two ways did Esau say Jacob had cheated him?

27.a: Isaac said that Esau would live away from the fatness of the earth, that he would serve his brother, but would eventually rebel against him and shake off Jacob's yoke.
27.q: What was the "blessing" that Isaac gave Esau?

27.a: Esau decided to kill Jacob after Isaac's death.
27.q: What did Esau decide to do after Isaac's death?

27.a: Rebekah sent Jacob to Laban, her brother, in Haran.
27.q: What did Rebekah do after hearing Esau's plans?

28.a: Isaac commanded Jacob not to take a Canaanite wife.
28.q: What command did Isaac give Jacob before he left?

28.a: Isaac told Jacob to get a wife from the daughters of Laban, Rebekah's brother.
28.q: Where did Isaac tell Jacob to get a wife?

28.a: Isaac asked God to give Jacob the blessing of Abraham.
28.q: Whose blessing did Isaac ask God to give Jacob?

28.a: Esau took a wife from the daughters of Ishmael, Abraham's son.
28.q: From where did Esau get one of his wives when he saw that the women of Canaan did not please Isaac?

28.a: Jacob saw a ladder from earth to heaven with angels ascending and descending on it, and Yahweh standing above it.
28.q: What did Jacob see in his dream while on the way to Haran?

28.a: Yahweh said that the land Jacob was lying on would be given to him and his descendants.
28.q: What did Yahweh say about the land Jacob was lying on?

28.a: Yahweh gave Jacob the blessing of Abraham.
28.q: Whose blessing did Yahweh give to Jacob?

28.a: Jacob said the place was the house of God and the gate of heaven.
28.q: What did Jacob say about the place where he had the dream?
What name did Jacob give the place where he had the dream?

28.a: Jacob said that Yahweh must be with him and protect him on his journey so that he returned safely to his father's house.
28.q: What did Jacob say Yahweh must do in order for Yahweh to be his God?

28.a: Jacob promised to give back to Yahweh a tenth of everything Yahweh gave Jacob.
28.q: What did Jacob promise to give Yahweh if Yahweh did these things for him?

29.q: From where were the men that Jacob talked to?

29.a: Rachel, daughter of Laban, also came to the well with a flock of sheep.
29.q: Who also came to the well with a flock of sheep?

29.a: Jacob rolled the stone from the well's mouth and watered the sheep.
29.q: What did Jacob do for Laban's sheep?

29.a: Jacob told Rachel that he was her father's relative, and then Rachel ran and told her father.
29.q: What did Jacob tell Rachel, and then what did she do?

29.a: Laban ran to meet Jacob, embraced him, kissed him, and brought him to his house.
29.q: How did Laban react when he heard about Jacob's arrival?

29.a: Leah was the older daughter and she had tender eyes, while Rachel was the younger and was beautiful in form and appearance.
29.q: Describe the two daughters of Laban.

29.a: They agreed that Jacob would serve Laban seven years in return for Rachel.
29.q: What arrangement did Laban and Jacob make concerning Jacob's labor?

29.a: The seven years of labor seemed only like a few days because of the love Jacob had for Rachel.
29.q: Why did the seven years of labor only seem like a few days to Jacob?

29.a: Laban gave Leah to Jacob, instead of Rachel, the night of the wedding.
Laban gave his female servant Zilpah to his daughter Leah, to be her servant.
29.q: Who did Laban give to Leah, to be her servant?

29.a: Laban said it was not their custom to give the younger daughter in marriage before the first-born.
29.q: Why did Laban say he had tricked Jacob?

29.a: They agreed that Jacob would serve Laban seven more years in return for Rachel.
29.q: What arrangement did Laban and Jacob then make concerning Jacob's labor?

29.a: Laban gave Bilhah to his daughter Rachel, to be her servant.
29.q: Who did Laban give to Rachel, to be her servant?

29.a: Yahweh caused Leah to become pregnant, but Rachel was childless.
29.q: What did Yahweh do when he saw that Jacob did not love Leah?

29.a: Leah hoped that Jacob would love her if she bore sons for him.
29.q: What did Leah hope would happen if she bore sons for Jacob?

29.a: The name of Leah's first son was Reuben.
29.q: What was the name of Leah's first son?

29.a: After she bore Judah Leah said, "This time I will praise Yahweh."
29.q: What did Leah say after she bore Judah?

30.a: According to Jacob, God had kept Rachel from having children.
30.q: According to Jacob, why did Rachel have no children?

30.a: Rachel gave Jacob Bilhah her servant so she could have children on Rachel's behalf.
30.q: What did Rachel do in order to have children?

30.a: Rachel said that she had prevailed because Bilhah her servant bore two sons for Jacob.
30.q: Why did Rachel say that she had prevailed against her sister Leah?

30.a: Leah gave Jacob Zilpah her servant so she could have children on Leah's behalf.
30.q: What did Leah do when she saw that she had stopped bearing children?

30.a: Leah said, "This is fortunate." because Zilpah her servant bore Jacob a son.
30.q: What caused Leah to say, "This is fortunate."?

30.a: In exchange for Reuben's mandrakes, Rachel offered to let Leah sleep with Jacob that night
30.q: What did Rachel offer Leah in exchange for her son's mandrakes?

30.a: Leah bore six sons for Jacob.
30.q: How many sons did Leah bear for Jacob?

30.a: When Rachel bore a son for Jacob, she said that her shame had been taken away.
30.q: What caused Rachel to say that her shame had been taken away?

30.a: Jacob requested that Laban let Jacob go with his family back to his own home and country.
30.q: What request did Jacob make to Laban after Joseph was born?

30.a: Laban had divined that Yahweh had blessed him for Jacob's sake.
30.q: Why did Laban not want to let Jacob go away?

30.a: Jacob took the speckled, spotted, and black sheep, and the speckled and spotted goats from Laban's flock that he tended.
30.q: What wages did Jacob receive for his work for Laban?

30.a: Laban first removed the animals that Jacob would have taken, before he gave the flock to Jacob to tend.
30.q: How did Laban cheat Jacob concerning Jacob's wages?

30.a: Jacob peeled white streaks into branches of fresh poplar, almond, and plane trees.
30.q: What kind of sticks did Jacob peel white streaks into?

30.q: What did Jacob do with the peeled sticks?

30.a: When the flocks bred in front of the sticks they produced striped, speckled, and spotted young.
30.q: What happened when the flocks bred in front of the sticks?

30.a: The result was that Laban's flock was feebler, and Jacob's flock was stronger.
30.q: What was the result of Jacob's breeding of the animals?

31.a: Laban and his sons believed that Jacob had gotten all his wealth from Laban's possessions.
31.q: From where did Laban and his sons believe Jacob had gotten all his wealth?

31.a: Yahweh instructed Jacob to return to the land of his fathers and to his relatives.
31.q: What instructions did Yahweh give Jacob?

31.a: God had caused the animals to bear speckled, and striped young which were Jacob's wages.
31.q: How had God taken away the cattle of Laban and given them to Jacob?

31.a: Rachel and Leah said that Laban treated them as foreigners and had devoured their money.
31.q: What attitude did Rachel and Leah have toward their father Laban?

31.a: Rachel stole her father's household gods.
31.q: What did Rachel do before leaving with Jacob?

31.a: Jacob deceived Laban by not telling Laban that he was leaving.
31.q: How did Jacob deceive Laban at this time?

31.a: Laban took his relatives with him and pursued Jacob, overtaking him after seven days.
31.q: What did Laban do when he was told that Jacob had fled?

31.a: God told Laban to speak neither good or bad to Jacob.
31.q: What did God tell Laban in a dream?

31.a: Jacob said that he fled secretly because he was afraid that Laban would take his daughters from him by force.
31.q: Why did Jacob say that he had fled from Laban secretly?

31.a: Jacob said that whoever stole Laban's household gods would not continue to live.
31.q: What did Jacob say when Laban accused him of stealing his household gods?

31.a: Laban did not find his household gods because Rachel sat on them and then said that she could not stand up since she was having her period.
31.q: Why did Laban not find his household gods among Jacob's possessions?

31.a: Jacob had worked for Laban twenty years, and Laban had changed his wages ten times.
31.q: How long had Jacob worked for Laban, and how many times had Laban changed his wages?

31.a: Laban said that all that he saw of Jacob's possessions was his.
31.q: How did Laban show that he still thought of Jacob's possessions as his own?

31.a: Jacob and Laban marked the place of their covenant by making a pile of stones there.
31.q: How did Jacob and Laban mark the place of their covenant?

31.a: Jacob and Laban each agreed to not pass beyond the pile of stones to do the other harm.
31.q: What covenant did Jacob and Laban make?

31.a: God was declared as witness between Jacob and Laban to ensure the covenant would be kept.

31.q: What were the pile and the pillar for?

31.q: What did Jacob do to show that he agreed to the covenant?

31.a: Laban rose, kissed his grandsons and daughters, blessed them, and returned home.
31.q: What did Laban do the next morning?

32.q: To whom did Jacob send a message on his way toward Canaan?

32.a: Jacob desired to find favor in Esau's sight.
32.q: For what purpose did Jacob send this message?

32.a: Jacob was afraid, so he divided his people into two groups so that if Esau attacked one group, the other could escape.
32.q: What was Jacob's reaction when he heard Esau was coming with four hundred men, and what did he do?

32.a: Jacob asked Yahweh to deliver him from the hand of Esau.
32.q: What was Jacob's request to Yahweh?

32.a: Jacob reminded Yahweh that he had promised to prosper Jacob, and to make is descendants like the sand of the sea.
32.q: Of what promise did Jacob remind Yahweh?

32.a: Jacob thought that perhaps he could appease Esau with the gifts that he sent to Esau so that later, when Jacob saw him, Esau would receive him.
32.q: What did Jacob think he could accomplish by sending gifts to his brother Esau?

32.a: He took his wives, servant women, and children across the ford of the Jabbok.
32.q: How did Jacob end up being alone that night?

32.a: Jacob wrestled with a man until daybreak.
32.q: What did Jacob do that night until daybreak?

32.a: The man struck Jacob's hip and dislocated it.
32.q: What did the man do when he could not defeat Jacob?

32.a: Jacob demanded that the man bless him.
32.q: What did Jacob demand before he would let the man go?

32.a: The man said that Jacob's name would now be Israel.
32.q: What did the man say Jacob would there after be called?

32.a: Jacob said he had seen God face to face that night.
32.q: Who did Jacob say he had seen face to face that night?

32.a: Jacob limped because of his hip after that night.
32.q: What physical problem did Jacob continue to have after that night?

33.a: Jacob put his female servants first, then Leah, and then Rachel.
33.q: As Esau was coming to Jacob, in what order did Jacob put his wives behind him?

33.a: Jacob bowed toward the ground seven times as he came near his brother.
33.q: What did Jacob do as he came near his brother?

33.q: What did Esau do when he came to his brother?

33.a: Esau told Jacob to keep them for himself, since he had enough.
33.q: What did Esau tell Jacob to do with the gifts he had sent ahead to Esau?

33.q: Why did Jacob say he wanted Esau to go ahead, while he traveled more slowly?

33.a: Jacob said he was going to bring his family and flocks to Esau in Seir.
33.q: Where did Jacob say he was going to bring his family and his flocks?

33.q: To where did Jacob travel, where he built himself a house?

33.a: Jacob traveled to Shechem, where he bought a piece of ground.
33.q: To where did Jacob travel, where he bought a piece of ground?

34.a: Shechem grabbed Dinah, assaulted her, and forced himself on her.
34.q: What did Shechem, the son of Hamor, do when he saw Dinah, Leah's daughter?

34.q: What did Jacob do at first when he heard about what happened to Dinah?
What was the reaction of Jacob's sons when they heard what Shechem had done to Dinah?

34.q: What did Hamor, the father of Shechem, want Jacob to do?

34.a: Shechem said he would pay as great a bride price as Jacob would name.
34.q: What did Shechem say he was willing to do to have Dinah as his wife?

34.a: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem deceitfully, because Shechem had defiled Dinah.
34.q: In what way did the sons of Jacob answer Shechem, and why?

34.a: The sons of Jacob required that all the males in Hamor's family be circumcised.
34.q: What requirement did the sons of Jacob make to Hamor before they would agree to intermarry with Hamor's family?

34.a: They said that all of Jacob's livestock, property, and animals would be theirs if they intermarried with Jacob's family.
34.q: When speaking to the men of their city, what did Hamor and Shechem say would be theirs if they intermarried with Jacob's family?

34.a: The men of Hamor's city listened to Hamor and Shechem and every male was circumcised.
34.q: How did the men of Hamor's city respond when asked if they were willing to be circumcised?

34.a: Simeon and Levi killed all the males in Hamor's city.
34.q: What did Simeon and Levi do on the third day after the males from Hamor's family had been circumcised?

34.a: All of the sons of Jacob looted the city, took all the wealth, and captured the children and wives.
34.q: What then did all of the sons of Jacob do?

34.a: Jacob said that Simeon and Levi had brought trouble on him because the inhabitants of the land might now destroy him and his household.
34.q: How did Jacob respond when he learned about what Simeon and Levi had done?

34.a: Simeon and Levi said they had done it because Shechem had treated their sister Dinah like a prostitute.
34.q: Why did Simeon and Levi say they had done it?

35.a: God told Jacob to go to Bethel and to build an altar to God.
35.q: What did God tell Jacob to go and do?

35.a: Jacob told them to put away their foreign gods, to purify themselves, and to change their clothes.
35.q: What did Jacob then tell the people of his household to do?

35.a: The people of the cities around them did not pursue them because they were afraid of God.
35.q: As they traveled, why did the people of the cities around Jacob and his household not pursue them?

35.a: Jacob called it "Elbethel" because it was the place God had revealed himself to Jacob when Jacob was fleeing from Esau.
35.q: Why did Jacob call the place they came to "Elbethel"?

35.a: God gave Jacob the new name Israel.
35.q: What new name did God give Jacob?

35.a: God reaffirmed the promise that Jacob would become a company of nations with kings among his descendants, and that the land God had promised to Abraham and Isaac would be given to him and his descendants.
35.q: What promise did God reaffirm to Jacob?

35.a: Rachel died during her labor with Benjamin.
35.q: What happened to Rachel during her labor with Benjamin?

35.a: Israel heard that Reuben had slept with Bilhah, Israel's concubine.
35.q: Israel heard about what thing that Reuben had done?
How many sons did Jacob have?

35.a: Joseph and Benjamin were born from Rachel.
35.q: Which sons of Jacob were born from Rachel?

35.a: Isaac lived one hundred eighty years.
35.q: How many years did Isaac live?

36.a: The descendants of Esau are also called Edom.
36.q: By what other name are the descendants of Esau called?

36.a: Esau took his wives from the Canaanites.
36.q: From where did Esau get his wives?

36.a: Esau moved away from his brother Jacob because the land could not support both of them as their possessions were too many.
36.q: Why did Esau move away from his brother Jacob?

36.a: Esau settled in the hill country of Seir.
The name of the son born by Timna was Amalek.
36.q: What was the name of the son born by Timna, a concubine of Esau's firstborn son Eliphaz?

36.a: Seir the Horite was the father of the inhabitants of the land in which Edom lived.
36.q: Who was the father of the inhabitants of the land in which Edom lived?

36.a: The people of Edom had kings before any king reigned over the Israelites.
36.q: What did the people of Edom have before Israel had them?

36.a: Esau was the father of the Edomites.
36.q: Who was the father of the Edomites?

37.a: Jacob lived in the land of Canaan.
37.q: Where did Jacob settle to live?

37.a: Joseph brought to his father an unfavorable report about his brothers.
37.q: What did Joseph bring to his father Jacob while guarding the flock with his brothers?

37.a: Israel made Joseph a luxurious tunic.
37.q: How did Israel show that he loved Joseph more than his other sons?

37.a: Joseph's brothers hated him and would not speak to him cordially.
37.q: What did Joseph's brothers think about Joseph?

37.a: Joseph saw his sheaf stand upright while his brothers' sheaves bowed down to his sheaf.
37.q: What did Joseph see in his first dream?

37.a: Joseph's brothers hated him even more.
37.q: What did Joseph's brothers think about Joseph after he told them about his first dream?

37.a: Joseph saw the sun, moon, and eleven stars bow down to him.
37.q: What did Joseph see in his second dream?

37.a: The sun, moon, and stars represented Joseph's father, mother, and brothers.
37.q: In Joseph's second dream, what did the sun, moon, and stars represent?

37.a: Jacob sent Joseph out of the valley of Hebron to see if it was well with his brothers, and to bring Jacob word.
37.q: What did Jacob send Joseph out of the valley of Hebron to do?

37.a: Joseph's brothers planned to kill Joseph and cast him into one of the pits.
37.q: What did Joseph's brothers plan to do when they saw Joseph coming?

37.a: Reuben suggested that the brothers only throw Joseph into a pit, so that he could rescue Joseph later.
37.q: What suggestion did Reuben make to his brothers, and why?

37.a: Joseph's brothers sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver.
37.q: Who did Joseph's brothers sell Joseph to and for how much?

37.a: Joseph's brothers killed a goat and dipped Joseph's coat in the blood, then gave the coat to Jacob.
37.q: How did Joseph's brothers make it appear that Joseph was dead?

37.a: Jacob tore his garments, wore sackcloth, and mourned his son for many days.
37.q: What did Jacob do after he concluded Joseph was dead?

37.a: Joseph was sold to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, in Egypt.
37.q: To whom was Joseph sold in Egypt?

38.a: Judah took a wife from a Canaanite man.
38.q: From whom did Judah take a wife?

38.a: Yahweh killed Er because he was wicked.
38.q: What did Yahweh do with Judah's first son Er, and why?

38.a: Onan would spill his semen on the ground when he made love to Tamar.
38.q: How did Judah's second son Onan not fulfill the duty of a brother-in-law to raise up a child for Er?

38.a: Yahweh killed Onan because what he did was evil.
38.q: What did Yahweh do with Judah's second son Onan, and why?

38.q: What promise did Judah then make to Tamar?

38.a: Judah was comforted because his wife died.
38.q: After a long time, why did Judah need to be comforted?

38.a: Tamar took off her clothing of widowhood, put on a veil and wrapped herself, and sat by the road to Timnah.
38.q: What did Tamar do when she heard that Judah was going to Timnah?

38.a: Tamar did this because Judah's third son Shelah had grown up, but she had not been given to him as a wife.
Judah gave Tamar his seal, cord, and staff as a pledge of payment.
38.q: What did Tamar obtain as a pledge for payment before Judah made love to her?

38.a: Judah learned that there was no temple prostitute in that area.
38.q: When Judah tried to retrieve his pledge by paying the prostitute with a young goat, what did he learn?

38.a: Judah wanted to burn Tamar because she had become pregnant as a prostitute.
38.q: What did Judah want to do when he learned that Tamar was pregnant?

38.a: She said that she was pregnant by the man who owned the seal, cord, and staff she had.
38.q: What did Tamar do when she was brought out to Judah?

38.a: Judah said that Tamar was more right than he was, because he had not given Tamar to Shelah as a wife.
38.q: How did Judah respond when he saw his seal, cord, and staff?
How many children did Tamar bear?

38.a: When one of Tamar's twins put his hand out from Tamar's womb The midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his hand and said, "This one came out first."
38.q: What did the midwife do when one of Tamar's twins put his hand out from Tamar's womb?

38.a: The names of the two brothers that Tamar birthed were Perez and Zerah.
38.q: What were the names of the two brothers that Tamar birthed?

39.a: Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh, bought Joseph in Egypt.
Joseph was prosperous because Yahweh was with him.
39.q: Why was Joseph prosperous in Egypt?

39.a: Potiphar put everything he had under Joseph's care.
39.q: What did Potiphar put under Joseph's care?

39.a: Potiphar's wife asked Joseph to make love to her.
39.q: What did Potiphar's wife ask Joseph to do?

39.a: Joseph refused and said he could not commit this great wickedness and sin against God.

39.q: What did Joseph do when Potiphar's wife caught him by his clothes?

39.q: What accusation did Potiphar's wife make against Joseph?

39.a: Potiphar became very angry and put Joseph in prison.
39.q: What did Potiphar do when he heard the accusation against Joseph?

39.a: Yahweh showed covenant faithfulness to Joseph at this time.
39.q: At this time, what did Yahweh show to Joseph?

39.q: What did the prison warden put under Joseph's care?
What was the result of everything Joseph did, and why?

40.a: They were both sad because no one could interpret their dreams.
40.q: Why were the cupbearer and baker both sad the next morning?

40.q: Who did Joseph say could give the interpretation of the dreams?

40.q: What did Joseph say was the interpretation of the cupbearer's dream?

40.a: Joseph requested that the cupbearer remember him, mention him to Pharaoh, and bring him out of the prison.
40.q: What request did Joseph make to the cupbearer after giving the interpretation of his dream?

40.q: What did Joseph say was the interpretation of the baker's dream?

40.a: Pharaoh's birthday was three days later.

40.q: What did Pharaoh do with the cupbearer and the baker on that day?

41.q: In Pharaoh's first dream, what did the seven thin cows do to the seven fat cows?

41.a: The seven thin ears swallowed up the seven full ears.
41.q: In Pharaoh's second dream, what did the seven thin ears of grain do to the seven full ears?

41.a: The magicians and wise men of Pharaoh could not interpret Pharaoh's dreams.
41.q: How did the magicians and wise men of Pharaoh interpret his dreams?

41.a: The chief cupbearer told Pharaoh that a young Hebrew man had correctly interpreted his dream and the dream of another fellow when they were in custody.
41.q: What did the chief cupbearer tell Pharaoh about Joseph?

41.a: Joseph said that God would answer Pharaoh's dream with favor.
41.q: Who did Joseph say would interpret Pharaoh's dream?

41.a: Joseph said that God was declaring to Pharaoh what God was about to do.
41.q: What did Joseph say God was declaring to Pharaoh?

41.a: The seven good cows and heads represented seven years of abundance.
41.q: What did the seven good cows and the seven good heads in the dreams represent?

41.a: The seven thin cows and heads represented seven years of famine.
41.q: What did the seven thin cows and the seven thin heads in the dreams represent?

41.a: Pharaoh was given two dreams because the matter had been established by God, and God would soon do it.
41.q: According to Joseph, why was Pharaoh given two dreams?

41.q: What fraction of the crops of Egypt did Joseph advise Pharaoh to take in the seven abundant years

41.a: Pharaoh said that the Spirit of God was in Joseph.
41.q: What did Pharaoh say was in Joseph?

41.a: Pharaoh gave Joseph authority over Pharaoh's house and over all the land of Egypt, second only to Pharaoh.
41.q: What position of authority did Pharaoh give Joseph?

41.a: Joseph stored up grain like the sand of the sea, an amount beyond counting.
41.q: How much grain did Joseph store up in the seven years of abundance?

41.a: Joseph's sons were named Manasseh and Ephraim.
41.q: What were the names of Joseph's two sons born before the famine?

41.a: The seven years of famine was in all lands.
41.q: How widespread was the seven years of famine?

41.q: What did Joseph do when the people of Egypt cried to Pharaoh for food?

41.q: Who came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph?

42.q: Who did Jacob send down to Egypt to buy grain?

42.a: Joseph's brothers bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.
42.q: What did Joseph's brothers do when they came to Joseph to buy grain?

42.a: Joseph disguised himself and spoke harshly with his brothers.
42.q: What did Joseph do when he recognized his brothers?

42.q: What accusation did Joseph make against his brothers?

42.a: Joseph's brothers said their youngest brother was with his father in the land of Canaan.
42.q: Where did Joseph's brothers say their youngest brother was?

42.a: Joseph's brothers said their other missing brother was no longer alive.
42.q: Where did Joseph's brothers say their other missing brother was?

42.a: Joseph said the brothers would not leave Egypt, unless their youngest brother came to Egypt.
42.q: What test did Joseph give his brothers to demonstrate they were not spies?

42.a: Joseph put the brothers in custody for three days.
42.q: Where did Joseph put the brothers and for how long?

42.a: Joseph told them to let one of the brothers be confined in prison, while the others carried grain to Canaan and brought back the youngest brother.
42.q: What did Joseph tell the brothers to do in order to live?

42.a: They believed that the blood of Joseph was being required of them for what they had done to Joseph.
42.q: Why did Joseph's brothers believe this trouble had come upon them?

42.a: When Joseph heard his brothers talking about what they had done to him, Joseph turned from them and wept.
42.q: What did Joseph do when he heard his brothers talk about what they had done to him?

42.a: Joseph had each brother's money put back in his sack.
42.q: What did Joseph have put back in each brother's sack?

42.a: Their hearts sank and they spoke trembling to one another.
42.q: How did the brothers react when they learned that one brother's sack had his money in it?

42.a: The brothers blamed God, asking why God had done this to them.
42.q: Who did the brothers blame for their current problems?

42.a: They learned that every man's money was in his sack.
42.q: What did the brothers and Jacob learn when they emptied all the sacks?

42.a: Jacob was afraid that Simeon and Benjamin would be taken away from him.
42.q: What was Jacob afraid would happen because of their situation?

42.a: Reuben swore to bring Benjamin back to Jacob from Egypt; otherwise, Reuben's two sons could be killed.
42.q: What oath did Reuben make to Jacob?

42.a: No, Jacob did not allow Reuben to take Benjamin to Egypt.

42.a: Jacob said he would go down with sorrow to Sheol if Benjamin died.

43.q: Why did Israel tell his sons to go again and buy some food in Egypt?

43.a: Judah said they must have their brother Benjamin in order to go down to Egypt.
43.q: What did Judah say they must have in order to go down to Egypt again?

43.a: Judah said that if he did not bring Benjamin back, he would bear the blame forever.
43.q: What oath did Judah make to Israel his father?

43.a: Israel told the brothers to take some of the best products of the land, and to take double the money.
43.q: What did Israel tell the brothers to take with them to Egypt?

43.a: Israel asked God to give the brothers mercy in Egypt, so that all the brothers would be released.
43.q: For what did Israel ask God regarding the journey?

43.q: How did the brothers respond when they were brought to Joseph's house, and why?

43.a: The steward said the money left in their sacks had come from their God.
43.q: From where did the steward say the money left in their sacks had come?

43.a: The brothers brought the gifts into the house, and bowed down before Joseph to the ground.
43.q: What did the brothers do when Joseph came home?

43.a: Joseph asked the brothers about the welfare of their father.
43.q: About whom did Joseph ask the brothers?

43.a: Joseph hurried out of the room because he was deeply moved about Benjamin, and he went to his room and wept.
43.q: Why did Joseph hurry to go out of the room, and what did he do after he left?

43.a: It was detestable to the Egyptians to eat with the Hebrews.
43.q: Why did the Egyptians and the Hebrews eat separately?

43.a: The brothers were arranged at the table according to their birthright and age.
43.q: How were the brothers arranged at the table?

43.a: Benjamin's portion was five times as much as any of his brothers.
43.q: What was unusual about the portions of food the brothers received?

44.q: What did Joseph tell his steward to do with the brothers' sacks before they left?

44.q: Basically what did Joseph tell the steward say to the brothers when he overtook them outside the city?

44.q: What did the brothers swear they would do if any one of them had stolen Joseph's cup?

44.q: What punishment did the steward say he would require if the cup was stolen?

44.a: The steward found the cup in Benjamin's sack, and the brothers tore their clothes.
44.q: What did the steward find, and how did the brothers react?

44.a: The brothers bowed before Joseph to the ground.
44.q: What did the brothers do when they came back to Joseph in his house?

44.a: Judah said that God had found out their iniquity.
44.q: Who did Judah say had found out the iniquity of the brothers?

44.a: Judah said all the brothers would now become Joseph's slaves.
44.q: What did Judah say all the brothers would now become?

44.a: Joseph said that the man in whose hand the cup was found would be his slave, and the rest could go in peace.
44.q: What punishment did Joseph say he would require of the brothers?

44.a: Judah said that the youngest brother was the child of his father's old age, and the only child left of his mother.
44.q: What reasons did Judah give for why his father loved the youngest brother?

44.a: The brothers worried their father would die if the youngest left him.
44.q: What did the brothers worry would happen to their father if the youngest left him?

44.a: Judah said they were forced to bring Benjamin because Joseph had said that unless the youngest brother comes, they would not see Joseph's face.
44.q: Why did Judah say the brothers were forced to bring Benjamin with them to Egypt?

44.a: Israel thought that surely Joseph had been torn in pieces.
44.q: What did Israel think had happened to Joseph?

44.a: Israel said that the brothers would bring his gray hair with sorrow to Sheol.
44.q: What did Israel say would happen to him if Benjamin were taken from him?

44.a: Judah said that his father would die.
44.q: What did Judah say would happen to his father if they returned without Benjamin?

44.a: Judah said that if he did not return Benjamin to his father, he would bear the guilt forever.
44.q: What guarantee for Benjamin did Judah say he had become?

44.a: Judah asked Joseph to make him Joseph's slave, so that Benjamin could return to his father.
44.q: What did Judah ask Joseph to do so that Benjamin could return to his father?

45.a: Joseph wept loudly as he made himself known to his brothers.
45.q: What did Joseph do as he made himself known to his brothers, which the Egyptians heard?

45.a: The brothers could not answer Joseph for they were shocked.
45.q: How did the brothers react when Joseph revealed himself to them?

45.a: God sent Joseph to Egypt to preserve life, and to preserve his family as a remnant in the earth.
45.q: According to Joseph, why did God sent Joseph to Egypt?

45.a: God had made Joseph father to Pharaoh, lord of all Pharaoh's house, and ruler over all the land of Egypt.
45.q: What had God made Joseph in the land of Egypt?

45.a: Joseph told his family to come and live in the land of Goshen where he would provide for them.
45.q: How did Joseph plan to take care of his family?

45.a: Joseph told his brothers to hurry and bring his father to Egypt.
45.q: What did Joseph tell his brothers to hurry and do?

45.a: Pharaoh was very pleased, and he told Joseph to tell his brothers to bring their father and their households to live in the good of the land of Egypt.
45.q: How did Pharaoh react when he heard that Joseph's brothers had come to Egypt?

45.a: Benjamin received three hundred pieces of silver and five changes of clothing, and Israel received twenty loaded donkeys.
45.q: Who received extra gifts and provisions for the trip?

45.a: Israel's heart was astonished, for he did not believe the brothers when they told him.
45.q: How did Israel react when he heard that Joseph was alive and ruler over all the land of Egypt?

45.a: Israel said he wanted to see Joseph before he died.
45.q: What did Israel say he wanted to do before he died?

46.a: Israel offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
46.q: What did Israel do in Beersheba?

46.a: God promised to make Israel a great nation, to go with Israel to Egypt, to bring Israel up again from Egypt, and to have Joseph close his eyes.
46.q: What promises did God make to Israel in Beersheba?

46.a: Israel and all his descendants with him went to Egypt.
46.q: Who went to Egypt with Israel?

46.a: Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
46.q: Which two sons of Judah died in the land of Canaan?

46.a: Seventy persons of the house of Jacob came to Egypt.
46.q: How many persons of the house of Jacob came to Egypt?

46.a: Joseph went up with his chariot and met his father Israel in Goshen.
46.q: What did Joseph do to meet his father?

46.a: Joseph hugged his father's neck and wept a long time.
46.q: What did Joseph do when he saw his father?

46.a: The brothers were to tell Pharaoh that they were keepers of cattle from their youth.
46.q: What did Joseph tell the brothers to say to Pharaoh concerning their occupation?

47.a: The five brothers told Pharaoh their occupation was shepherding.
47.q: What did the five brothers of Joseph tell Pharaoh their occupation was?

47.a: The brothers said they were temporary residents in the land of Egypt.
47.q: What kind of residents did the brothers say they were in the land of Egypt?

47.a: Pharaoh told Joseph to settle Joseph's family in the best region, the land of Goshen.
47.q: What did Pharaoh tell Joseph to do with Joseph's family?

47.a: Jacob had lived one hundred and thirty years.
47.q: How long had Jacob lived when he met Pharaoh?

47.a: Jacob said his life was not as long as his ancestors' lives.
47.q: How long did Jacob say his life was compared to his ancestors?

47.a: Jacob blessed Pharaoh when he met him and when he went out from his presence.
47.q: What did Jacob do for Pharaoh when he met him and when he went out from his presence?

47.a: Joseph was able to gather up all the money in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan.
47.q: What was Joseph able to do by selling grain?

47.a: Joseph was able to exchange food for all the livestock of the Egyptians.
47.q: What was Joseph then able to do by exchanging food with the Egyptians?

47.a: The people of Egypt offered their land and themselves as servants of Pharaoh in exchange for more food.
47.q: After the money and livestock were all given to Pharaoh in exchange for food what did the people of Egypt offer Pharaoh in exchange for more food?

47.a: Joseph required one fifth of the harvest to be given to Pharaoh.
47.q: What part of the whole harvest did Joseph require to be given to Pharaoh?

47.a: The people of Israel gained possessions in the land of Egypt, and they were fruitful and multiplied rapidly.
47.q: In what ways did the people of Israel prosper in the land of Egypt?

47.a: Jacob died at the age of one hundred forty-seven.
47.q: At what age did Jacob die?

47.a: Israel asked Joseph to swear he would bury Israel in his forefathers' burial place.
47.q: What did Israel ask Joseph to swear he would do?

48.a: Joseph heard that his father was sick, so he took with him his two sons.
48.q: What message did Joseph hear about his father, and what did he then do?

48.a: Jacob recalled that God promised him he would be fruitful and multiply, he would be made an assembly of nations, and the land of Canaan would be an everlasting possession of his descendants.
48.q: What promises from God did Jacob recall to Joseph?

48.a: Jacob said he would consider the two sons of Joseph as his own.
48.q: How did Jacob say he would consider the two sons of Joseph in the inheritance?

48.a: Israel did not recognize Joseph's two sons because his eyes were failing because of his age.
48.q: Why did Israel not recognize Joseph's two sons?

48.a: Manasseh was the first-born of Joseph's sons.
48.q: Who was the first-born of Joseph's sons?

48.a: Israel put his right hand on Ephraim, and his left hand on Manasseh.
48.q: Upon whom did Israel put his right hand, and upon whom his left hand?

48.a: Joseph expected Israel's right hand to be on Manasseh because he was the first-born.
48.q: Why did Joseph try to exchange the position of Israel's hands?

48.a: Israel refused because the younger brother would be greater than the first-born.
48.q: Why did Israel refuse to exchange the position of his hands on the two sons of Joseph?

48.a: Israel said the people of Israel would pronounce the blessing, "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh".
48.q: What blessing did Israel say the people of Israel would pronounce?

48.a: Israel said that Joseph would be brought back to the land of his fathers.
48.q: What did Israel say would happen to Joseph?

49.a: Jacob gathered his sons together to tell them what would happen to them and their descendants in the future.
49.q: For what reason did Jacob gather his sons together?

49.a: Reuben was outstanding in dignity and power.
49.q: What positive attributes did Reuben have?

49.a: Reuben would not have the pre-eminence because he defiled his father's bed.
49.q: Why would Reuben not have the pre-eminence even though he was the firstborn?

49.a: Jacob cursed the fierce and cruel anger of Simeon and Levi.
49.q: What did Jacob curse about Simeon and Levi?

49.a: Jacob said his others sons would bow down before Judah.
49.q: What did Jacob say his other sons would do before Judah?

49.a: Judah was promised that the sceptre would not depart from him until Shiloh came, and that the nations would obey him.
49.q: What promises about the future were made to Judah?

49.a: Jacob said the descendants of Zebulun would live by the shore of the sea.
49.q: Where did Jacob say the descendants of Zebulun would live?

49.a: Jacob said Dan would be like a poisonous snake.
49.q: What animal did Jacob say Dan would be like?

49.a: Jacob said Asher would be known for providing royal delicacies.
49.q: For what did Jacob say Asher would be known?

49.a: Jacob said Joseph would be like a fruitful bough whose branches climb over a wall.
49.q: What kind of plant did Jacob say Joseph would be like?

49.a: Jacob said the hands of the mighty one of Jacob, the Rock of Israel would keep Joseph's bow steady and his hands skillful.
49.q: Who did Jacob say would keep Joseph's bow steady and his hands skillful?

49.a: Abraham, Sarah, Isaac, Rebekah, and Leah were already buried there.
49.q: Who was already buried in the place where Jacob wished to be buried?

49.a: Jacob breathed his last and went to his people.
49.q: What did Jacob do after he gave his blessings and instructions to his sons?

50.q: What did Joseph do with Israel's body after Israel died?

50.a: Joseph requested to be able to go to the land of Canaan to bury his father, as his father had made him swear.
50.q: What request did Joseph make to Pharaoh about the burial of his father, and why did he make this request?

50.a: All the officials of Pharaoh, the courtiers of his household, the senior officials of Egypt, Joseph's household, Joseph's brothers, his father's household, and chariots and horsemen all went with Joseph.
50.q: Who went with Joseph to bury Israel?

50.a: The Canaanites said that this was a very sad occasion for the Egyptians.
50.q: What did the Canaanites say when they saw Joseph and those with him?

50.a: Joseph and his brothers returned into Egypt.
50.q: Where did Joseph and his brothers go after burying their father?

50.a: Joseph's brothers were worried that Joseph would repay them for all the evil the brothers had done to Joseph.
50.q: About what were Joseph's brothers worried after Israel died?

50.a: The brothers asked Joseph to forgive them for the wrongs they had committed against Joseph.
50.q: What did the brothers ask Joseph to do regarding the wrongs they had committed against Joseph?

50.a: When they came to Joseph, Joseph's brothers fell down before him.
50.q: What did Joseph's brothers do when they came to Joseph?

50.a: Joseph said God had worked the good of preserving the lives of many people.
50.q: What good did Joseph say God had worked through the evil deeds of his brothers?

50.a: Joseph lived one hundred and ten years.
Joseph said that he was about to die.
50.q: What did Joseph say was about to happen to him?

50.a: Joseph said God would come to the people and lead them up to the land God promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
50.q: What promise did Joseph say God would fulfill for Israel's descendants?

50.a: Joseph made them swear they would carry Joseph's bones from Egypt when they left Egypt.
50.q: What did Joseph make the people of Israel swear they would do?

50.a: Joseph's body was embalmed and put in a coffin in Egypt.
50.q: What happened to Joseph's body after he died?
